Package gov.va.med.srcalc.service

This is the Service Layer for the Surgical Risk Calculator, that is, the Domain Model's primary interface to the outside world.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    AdminService
    Service Layer facade for administering risk model definitions (including specialties).
    CalculationService
    Service Layer facade for performing risk calculations.
    ModelInspectionService
    Retrieves various Risk Model objects for inspection.
    ReportService
    Service Layer facade for generating reports.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    DefaultAdminService
    The canonical implementation of AdminService.
    DefaultCalculationService
    The canonical implementation of CalculationService.
    DefaultReportService
    Canonical implementation of ReportService.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    DuplicateRuleNameException
    Indicates that the code tried to save a new rule with the same rule display name as another rule.
    DuplicateVariableKeyException
    Indicates that the code tried to save a new variable with the same variable key as another variable.
    InvalidIdentifierException
    Indicates that the Service Layer received an invalid identifier (e.g., a specialty name) from the caller.

Package gov.va.med.srcalc.service Description

This is the Service Layer for the Surgical Risk Calculator, that is, the Domain Model's primary interface to the outside world. Unlike the Domain Model, which consists of many objects with many fine-grained interfaces, these classes present fewer, higher-level business operations.

Beyond facilitating interaction with the Domain Model, these business-operation-oriented methods present a natural transaction boundary and therefore most of them represent one transaction.

Since entry-point methods in the Service Layer represent transactions, many methods accept persistent object identifiers instead of objects themselves in order to encapsulate database interaction within the transaction. For example, CalculationService.setSpecialty accepts a String identifying a specialty instead of the specialty object itself. Other methods, such as AdminService.updateVariable, do accept domain objects but still encapsulate a single transaction.
